{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3634118,"name":"Çağan","username":"Myth","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/e480ec/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-23T11:06:26.728Z","cooked":"

A system came to my mind in order to minimize the errors of drivers. The robot will always know where it is in the match, and when the teleopa passes, for example, we will press the L4 key and go and throw it, then we will only press one button again to buy coral and the robot will go to the station and when we get the coral, we will say L4 again.

In short, the logic is like this, but other than that, for example, when a robot defends you, it will aim to apply the same power to it and stay constant, or, for example, it will encounter an obstacle in front of it (may be alga) and be able to walk around it and pass it.

Apart from these, it may be difficult to complete the whole match semi-autonomously, for example, he can climb the cage or algae comes under a teammate of ours. For such scenarios, in our drive system, there will be a keypad (even a computer) in order to give these commands that I said at the beginning, and among the things I just said, there will be the ps5 controller that we normally use when driving the robot.

In summary, I want to apply the logic of a robot vacuum cleaner, and it will be necessary to use many sensors for this. So is it possible to do this or is there a team that does?

I’m sorry if there are translation errors

This level of automation is absolutely possible. Many teams have on-the-fly pathing to automatically score coral, and they keep track of where they need to score for ranking points or score. This lets the robot decide where to put the pieces, which eliminates human lag. I’d look at team 6328 for examples, because they do a lot of automation and share all their resources.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-05-23T11:31:41.182Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":274,"readers_count":273,"score":84.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502281,"topic_slug":"semi-autonomous-system","display_username":"Nolan Barker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65568,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Lead, Co-captain | 3414 Hackbots"},"post_url":"/t/semi-autonomous-system/502281/2","custom_user_title":"Programming Lead, Co-captain | 3414 Hackbots","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3634130,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-23T11:32:10.494Z","cooked":"

There are teams that have tried working on approaches for this, but it has yet to be completely worth it for a team to use in a match. The issue is that humans can think two steps ahead and plan routes around things a robot just couldn’t reasonably predict. Also, the vantage point from the driver station tends to be better for getting a full scope and sense of a match compared to a robot-mounted sensor/camera.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-05-23T11:32:10.494Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":262,"readers_count":261,"score":72.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502281,"topic_slug":"semi-autonomous-system","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/semi-autonomous-system/502281/3","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3634133,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-23T11:38:50.723Z","cooked":"

If I’m understanding what I talked with them about at worlds, teams like 254 implement adaptive pathing algorithms that avoid obstacles like defense automatically if they collide rather than trying to continue on the current path. It’s not always the best way to avoid defense, but most of the time it works well. If there are no other robots in the way (which isn’t always the case but is often) a teams automatic pathing is often much faster than a human driver and less prone to joystick error or a poor line of sight (think bad sides of reef).
The ability to strategically plan a match is also a feature that you can implement. Telling the robot your “coral priorities” could change the levels that the robot automatically picks. A human can use a device to select branches and levels of the reef that have been scored by other teams, and the robot automatically responds by not scoring there.
As of right now, fully automated algae isn’t something I’ve seen but it would be possible using similar techniques.

therekrab:

As of right now, fully automated algae isn’t something I’ve seen but it would be possible using similar techniques.

I’ve seen plenty of teams have fully automated algae cycles. Just watch any Einstein match for the first 15 seconds.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-05-23T15:14:09.242Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":141,"readers_count":140,"score":53.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502281,"topic_slug":"semi-autonomous-system","display_username":"Ada T","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/fairviewrobotics/2025-robot-code","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - fairviewrobotics/2025-robot-code: The code for the Black Knights Robotics 2025 Reefscape robot","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60586,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1157 team captain, 2036 electrical lead 2024"},"post_url":"/t/semi-autonomous-system/502281/9","custom_user_title":"1157 team captain, 2036 electrical lead 2024","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3634329,"name":"Jonah Bonner","username":"jonahb55","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-23T15:41:45.147Z","cooked":"

We have a lot of the foundation that could enable autonomous navigation around obstacles in theory. We’re able to reliably track the robot pose, reef state, and most game pieces on the floor. In both 2023 and 2025 we used that data to automate a large part of the game, including complex sequencing/field navigation for scoring, automatic strategy to optimize game piece placements, and auto alignment/sequencing for intaking. At some of our events this year, the robot was fully autonomous for over 50% of the match time (and partially autonomous for even longer). With some relatively minor additions (e.g. extra cameras, retraining models) we could, in principle, track other robots too. At that point there’s no reason we necessarily couldn’t develop ways to automate the rest of the match in a similar fashion.

But just because we can doesn’t mean we should. Fully automating the robot has never been our goal; we view automation as enabling human drivers to get better where they already excel. Dealing with the moment-to-moment movement of robots around the field will always be difficult for software to handle because it’s fundamentally about the gameplay of the alliance and not any individual robot. We want to free up the driver to focus on those high-level optimizations so that they don’t need to spend as much time practicing and thinking about the smaller details. Essentially, our goal is to use automation to make the driver better and not to put them out of a job.
